assessments.summary_mne: Šutnja vlade suočena sa ponovljenim javnim protestima residents Gornje Gorice zbog nacionalizovane zemlje stvara rastući rizik za javni red i narušava institucionalno povjerenje. Iako su protesti do sada bili mirni, odsustvo bilo kakvog zvaničnog kanala za dijalog povećava vjerovatnoću eskalacije. Sa aspekta unutrašnje bezbjednosti, neodgovaranje vlade predstavlja neuspjeh administrativnog kapaciteta koji prebacuje teret upravljanja građanskim pritužbama na organe reda umjesto na institucije koje su najbolje pozicionirane da ih riješe.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Odbijanje vlade da stupi u dijalog sa protestantima iz Gornje Gorice u vezi nacionalizovane zemlje predstavlja negativan razvoj sa aspekta javne bezbjednosti. Glavna briga Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova je da će nastavljena šutnja vlade eskalirati tenzije, potencijalno transformišući mirne demonstracije u incidente narušavanja javnog reda. Preporučujemo da vlada odmah otvori strukturiran mehanizam dijaloga dok Ministarstvo osigurava proporcionalno, prava poštujuće vođenje policijskih postupaka tokom aktuelnih protesta.
key_concerns_mne: Rizik od eskalacije: Dva protesta u tri dana bez odgovora vlade stvaraju putanju ka većim, konfrontativnijim demonstracijama u blizini osjetljivih državnih institucija

Preopterećenje policije: Ponovljena angažovanja policije na protestima blizu Skupštine opterećuju resurse Uprave policije u Podgorici i stavljaju policajce u neprikladnu posredničku ulogu između građana i vlade koja ne reaguje

Potencijal za vanjsku manipulaciju: Presjecanje restitucije zemlje, politički osjetljive istorije vlasništva Plantaža i frustracije građana stvara uslove gdje akteri povezani sa organizovanim kriminalom ili politički motivisani akteri mogu iskoristiti legitimne pritužbe

Administrativni neuspjeh: Odsustvo bilo kakvog vladinog kanala za dijalog — čak i formalnog priznanja prijema zahtjeva — krši osnovne principe odgovorne vladavine i prebacuje institucionalni neuspjeh na organe reda
Rizik od precedenta: Ako se šutnja vlade doživljava kao uspješna u suzbijanju zahtjeva, druge zajednice sa sličnim restitucijskim zahtjevima mogu usvojiti agresivnije protest taktike od samog početka

Izdati interne smjernice Uprave policije za proporcionalno, prava poštujuće vođenje policijskih postupaka tokom aktuelnih protesta, naglašavajući taktike deeskalacije i striktno pridržavanje Zakona o javnim skupovima

Aktivirati situaciono praćenje (obavještajni podaci iz otvorenih izvora i terenska veza) radi otkrivanja bilo kakvih znakova vanjske manipulacije, infiltracije provokatorima ili eksploatacije protestnog pokreta od strane organizovanog kriminala

Dokumentovati sva angažovanja policije povezana sa protestima i pripadajuće troškove kako bi se Vladi pružila jasna slika fiskalnog i operativnog tereta koji politička neaktivnost nameće Ministarstvu unutrašnjih poslova
Sarađivati sa opštinskim vlastima u Podgorici kako bi se osiguralo da se sva buduća obavještenja o protestima obrađuju transparentno i da su ustavna prava učesnika protesta u potpunosti zaštićena

assessments.summary: The government's silence in response to the Gornja Gorica residents' protests over nationalized land raises serious concerns from a rule-of-law and human rights perspective. The absence of any public engagement or institutional dialogue mechanism undermines the constitutional right to property, the right to petition, and the obligation of the state to provide effective legal remedies for historical injustices. While the underlying issue of 1960s-era nationalization is legally complex, the government's failure to respond — even procedurally — signals institutional neglect and risks eroding public trust in the legal order.
assessments.executive_summary: The government's refusal to engage with Gornja Gorica residents protesting the seizure of their ancestral land is a rule-of-law failure that implicates constitutional property rights and EU accession obligations under Chapter 23. The Ministry of Justice recommends the immediate establishment of a structured restitution dialogue process and a comprehensive review of outstanding denationalization claims.
assessments.reasoning:
The protest by Gornja Gorica residents concerns land nationalized in 1962 during the socialist era, subsequently transferred to the state-owned enterprise Plantaže. This is not an isolated grievance but part of a broader, unresolved legacy of communist-era property confiscation that Montenegro has never fully addressed through a comprehensive restitution or denationalization law.

From a constitutional standpoint, Article 58 of the Constitution of Montenegro guarantees the right to property, and Article 58(2) provides that property rights may only be restricted in the public interest with fair compensation. While the original nationalization predates the current constitutional order, the continued retention of that property by a state-owned enterprise — without any restitution process or compensation mechanism — creates an ongoing interference with property rights that the current state must answer for. The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) has consistently held, in cases such as Broniowski v. Poland and Pinheiro Principles contexts, that systemic failures to address historical property deprivations can constitute continuing violations of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 (protection of property).

The government's complete silence is particularly troubling. Article 56 of the Constitution guarantees the right to petition, and citizens exercising this right through peaceful protest are entitled to at minimum a procedural acknowledgment. The absence of any response — not even a commitment to review the matter — suggests a disregard for participatory governance and the principle that the state must be accountable to its citizens. This is not merely a political shortcoming; it is a rule-of-law deficit.

Regarding EU harmonization, Montenegro's progress on Chapter 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) is closely monitored by the European Commission. Property rights and the rule of law are foundational to the EU legal order. The European Commission's annual reports on Montenegro have repeatedly noted the need for stronger protection of property rights and more transparent land administration. The unresolved status of nationalized properties, combined with the entanglement of state-owned enterprises like Plantaže, also raises anti-corruption concerns — particularly regarding whether politically connected interests have benefited from the continued state control of these assets at the expense of rightful claimants.

Montenegro notably lacks a comprehensive denationalization or restitution law comparable to those adopted in Croatia (1996), Serbia (2011), or Slovenia (1991). Partial mechanisms exist, but they have been widely criticized as inadequate, non-transparent, and slow. The Gornja Gorica case exemplifies the consequences of this legislative gap. Without a clear legal framework, affected citizens are left with no effective remedy — forced to resort to street protests rather than legal proceedings.

The involvement of Plantaže adds another layer of complexity. As a state-owned enterprise that has been the subject of privatization discussions and corruption allegations in the past, the retention of nationalized land by Plantaže raises questions about whether the state's inaction is driven by legitimate legal considerations or by the desire to protect commercial and political interests tied to the company.

Finally, the right to peaceful assembly (Article 52 of the Constitution) is being exercised by these residents, and the government's duty is not merely to tolerate the protest but to engage with the substantive demands in good faith. The Venice Commission and OSCE/ODIHR guidelines on freedom of peaceful assembly emphasize that the right to protest carries with it an implicit obligation on the state to facilitate dialogue.
key_concerns: Complete absence of government response to citizens exercising their constitutional right to petition and peaceful assembly, signaling a rule-of-law deficit

Montenegro's lack of a comprehensive denationalization or restitution law leaves victims of communist-era property confiscation without an effective legal remedy, contrary to ECHR Article 1 Protocol 1 standards
Potential continuing violation of the constitutional right to property (Article 58) through the state's retention — via Plantaže — of land seized without compensation or restitution process
EU Chapter 23 benchmarks on property rights protection and effective legal remedies are not being met, which could impede Montenegro's accession progress
Anti-corruption risk: the entanglement of state-owned enterprise Plantaže with nationalized land raises questions about whether political or commercial interests are driving the government's inaction

Risk of escalation: prolonged government silence may lead to intensified protests, civil unrest, or radicalization of grievances that could have been resolved through institutional channels
recommendations: The government should issue an immediate public acknowledgment of the residents' demands and commit to establishing a structured dialogue process within a defined timeframe (e.g., 30 days)

The Ministry of Justice should initiate a comprehensive legislative review with the aim of drafting a denationalization/restitution law, drawing on best practices from Croatia, Serbia, and Slovenia, and in consultation with the Venice Commission

Establish an independent inter-ministerial commission — including representatives from the Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Finance, and the Property Directorate — to audit all outstanding claims related to 1960s-era nationalized land, with a particular focus on Gornja Gorica

Conduct a transparent legal and financial audit of Plantaže's landholdings to determine which parcels originate from nationalized private property and assess the legal basis for their continued state control

Engage the Ombudsman (Protector of Human and Minority Rights) to investigate systemic failures in addressing historical property claims and issue recommendations

counter_proposal.title: Comprehensive Denationalization Framework and Gornja Gorica Resolution Mechanism
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than maintaining silence and forcing citizens to rely on street protests, the Ministry of Justice would propose a dual-track approach: (1) an immediate, case-specific mediation process for the Gornja Gorica residents, led by an independent mediator appointed by the Ministry, with Plantaže and the Property Directorate as parties, aiming to reach a settlement — whether through land restitution, compensation, or land exchange — within 6 months; and (2) a broader legislative initiative to draft and adopt a comprehensive Denationalization and Restitution Act by the end of 2027, modeled on successful regional frameworks, which would create a permanent administrative body to process all outstanding claims from the communist era, with clear deadlines, transparent procedures, and judicial review mechanisms.
key_changes: Establish an immediate mediation process for Gornja Gorica claims, with a 6-month resolution target and an independent mediator
Draft a comprehensive Denationalization and Restitution Act with clear eligibility criteria, claim deadlines, and remedies (restitution in kind, compensation, or land swap)
Create a permanent Restitution Commission as an independent administrative body to process all historical property claims
Mandate a full land audit of state-owned enterprises — starting with Plantaže — to identify all parcels originating from nationalized private property
Guarantee free legal aid for all claimants in denationalization proceedings
Introduce judicial review of all Restitution Commission decisions before the Administrative Court, ensuring due process
expected_benefits: Resolves the immediate Gornja Gorica grievance through structured dialogue rather than escalating confrontation
Fills a critical legislative gap that has persisted for over three decades since Montenegro's democratic transition
Strengthens Montenegro's EU accession prospects by demonstrating commitment to property rights and rule of law under Chapter 23
Reduces corruption risk by transparently auditing state-owned enterprise landholdings and severing political influence over property decisions
Restores public trust in the legal system by providing effective remedies for historical injustices
Creates legal certainty for land ownership, benefiting the investment climate and real estate market
Aligns Montenegro with regional best practices and ECHR jurisprudence on property restitution
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: The immediate mediation process for Gornja Gorica is highly feasible and could be initiated within weeks through a government decision or ministerial order, requiring minimal legislative change. The broader Denationalization Act is a medium-term undertaking (18-24 months) that would require significant political will, inter-ministerial coordination, fiscal impact assessments, and parliamentary support. However, regional precedents demonstrate that such legislation is achievable, and technical assistance from the EU (through IPA funds) and the Council of Europe (Venice Commission) could substantially support the drafting process. The main obstacle is political, not technical — successive governments have avoided this issue due to the fiscal implications and the interests of state-owned enterprises. A clear government commitment, potentially catalyzed by the current public pressure, is the critical enabling factor.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Sveobuhvatni okvir za denacionalizaciju i mehanizam rješavanja spora u Gornjoj Gorici
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da održava tišinu i prisiljava građane da se oslanjaju na ulične proteste, Ministarstvo pravde bi predložilo pristup sa dva pravca: (1) hitan, pojedinačni medijacijski proces za stanovnike Gornje Gorice, vođen nezavisnim medijatorom koga imenuje Ministarstvo, sa Plantažama i Upravom za imovinu kao stranama, sa ciljem postizanja nagodbe — bilo kroz povrat zemljišta, kompenzaciju ili razmjenu zemljišta — u roku od 6 mjeseci; i (2) širu zakonodavnu inicijativu za izradu i usvajanje sveobuhvatnog Zakona o denacionalizaciji i restituciji do kraja 2027. godine, po uzoru na uspješne regionalne okvire, koji bi stvorio stalno administrativno tijelo za obradu svih preostalih zahtjeva iz komunističke ere, sa jasnim rokovima, transparentnim procedurama i mehanizmima sudskog preispitivanja.
key_changes_mne: Uspostaviti hitan medijacijski proces za zahtjeve iz Gornje Gorice, sa ciljem rješavanja u roku od 6 mjeseci i nezavisnim medijatorom

Izraditi sveobuhvatni Zakon o denacionalizaciji i restituciji sa jasnim kriterijumima prihvatljivosti, rokovima za podnošenje zahtjeva i pravnim lijekovima (povrat u naravi, kompenzacija ili razmjena zemljišta)
Osnovati stalnu Komisiju za restituciju kao nezavisno administrativno tijelo za obradu svih istorijskih imovinskih zahtjeva
Naložiti potpunu reviziju zemljišta preduzeća u državnom vlasništvu — počevši sa Plantažama — radi identifikacije svih parcela koje potiču od nacionalizovane privatne imovine
Garantovati besplatnu pravnu pomoć za sve podnosioce zahtjeva u denacionalizacionim postupcima
Uvesti sudsko preispitivanje svih odluka Komisije za restituciju pred Upravnim sudom, obezbijedivši pravilnost postupka

Jača izglede Crne Gore za pristupanje EU demonstrirajući posvećenost imovinskim pravima i vladavini prava u okviru Poglavlja 23

counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Hitni medijacijski proces za Gornju Goricu je visoko izvodljiv i mogao bi biti pokrenut u roku od nekoliko sedmica putem vladine odluke ili ministarskog rješenja, zahtijevajući minimalne zakonodavne izmjene. Širi Zakon o denacionalizaciji je srednjoročni poduhvat (18-24 mjeseca) koji bi zahtijevao značajnu političku volju, međuresornu koordinaciju, procjene fiskalnog uticaja i podršku parlamenta. Međutim, regionalni precedenti pokazuju da je takvo zakonodavstvo ostvarivo, a tehnička pomoć EU (kroz IPA fondove) i Savjeta Evrope (Venecijanska komisija) mogla bi značajno podržati proces izrade. Glavna prepreka je politička, a ne tehnička — uzastopne vlade su izbjegavale ovo pitanje zbog fiskalnih implikacija i interesa preduzeća u državnom vlasništvu. Jasna vladina posvećenost, potencijalno podstaknuta trenutnim pritiskom javnosti, predstavlja ključni omogućavajući faktor.

assessments.summary_mne: Šutnja vlade kao odgovor na proteste stanovnika Gornje Gorice zbog nacionalizovane zemlje izaziva ozbiljne zabrinutosti sa aspekta vladavine prava i ljudskih prava. Odsustvo bilo kakvog javnog angažmana ili institucionalnog dijaloškog mehanizma potkopava ustavno pravo na imovinu, pravo na peticiju i obavezu države da obezbijedi efikasna pravna sredstva za istorijske nepravde. Iako je osnovno pitanje nacionalizacije iz 1960-ih pravno složeno, neuspjeh vlade da odgovori — čak i proceduralno — ukazuje na institucionalno zanemarivanje i rizikuje narušavanje javnog povjerenja u pravni poredak.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Odbijanje vlade da se angažuje sa stanovnicima Gornje Gorice koji protestuju zbog oduzimanja njihove prađedovske zemlje predstavlja neuspjeh vladavine prava koji implicira ustavna imovinska prava i obaveze EU pristupanja prema Poglavlju 23. Ministarstvo pravde preporučuje hitno uspostavljanje strukturiranog dijaloškog procesa restitucije i sveobuhvatan pregled nerješenih zahtjeva za denacionalizaciju.
key_concerns_mne: Potpuno odsustvo odgovora vlade na građane koji ostvaruju svoje ustavno pravo na peticiju i mirno okupljanje, što ukazuje na deficit vladavine prava

Nedostatak sveobuhvatnog zakona o denacionalizaciji ili restituciji u Crnoj Gori ostavlja žrtve komunističke konfiskacije imovine bez efikasnog pravnog sredstva, suprotno standardima člana 1 Protokola 1 ECHR-a
Potencijalno trajno kršenje ustavnog prava na imovinu (član 58) kroz zadržavanje zemlje od strane države — putem Plantaža — koja je zaplijenjena bez nadoknade ili procesa restitucije
Ne ispunjavaju se mjerila EU Poglavlja 23 o zaštiti imovinskih prava i efikasnim pravnim sredstvima, što bi moglo ometati napredak Crne Gore ka pristupanju
Antikorupcijski rizik: isprepletanost državnog preduzeća Plantaže sa nacionalizovanom zemljom pokreće pitanja o tome da li politički ili komercijalni interesi pokreću nečinjenje vlade
Odsustvo transparentnih institucionalnih mehanizama za rješavanje istorijskih imovinskih zahtjeva stvara pravnu nesigurnost, potkopava investicionu klimu i nesrazmjerno pogađa ugrožene populacije
Rizik od eskalacije: produžena šutnja vlade može dovesti do intenzivnijih protesta, građanskih nemira ili radikalizacije pritužbi koje su mogle biti riješene putem institucionalnih kanala
recommendations_mne: Vlada bi trebalo da izda hitno javno priznanje zahtjeva stanovnika i obaveže se na uspostavljanje strukturiranog dijaloškog procesa u definisanom vremenskom okviru (npr. 30 dana)

Ministarstvo pravde bi trebalo pokrenuti sveobuhvatan zakonodavni pregled sa ciljem izrade zakona o denacionalizaciji/restituciji, oslanjajući se na najbolje prakse iz Hrvatske, Srbije i Slovenije, i u konsultaciji sa Venecijanskom komisijom

Uspostaviti nezavisnu međuresornu komisiju — uključujući predstavnike Ministarstva pravde, Ministarstva finansija i Uprave za imovinu — za reviziju svih nerješenih zahtjeva vezanih za nacionalizovanu zemlju iz 1960-ih, sa posebnim fokusom na Gornju Goricu

Sprovesti transparentnu pravnu i finansijsku reviziju zemljišnih posjeda Plantaža kako bi se utvrdilo koje parcele potiču iz nacionalizovane privatne imovine i procijenio pravni osnov za njihovu kontinuiranu državnu kontrolu

Osigurati da pogođeni stanovnici imaju pristup besplatnoj pravnoj pomoći (prema Zakonu o besplatnoj pravnoj pomoći) kako bi ostvarili svoje zahtjeve putem postojećih sudskih kanala dok se sistemske reforme razvijaju

Angažovati Ombudsmana (Zaštinika ljudskih i manjinskih prava) da istraži sistemske neuspjehe u rješavanju istorijskih imovinskih zahtjeva i izda preporuke

assessments.summary: The government's silence in response to the Gornja Gorica residents' protests over nationalized land tied to state-owned Plantaže is economically concerning. Unresolved property rights disputes undermine investor confidence, block productive land use, create legal uncertainty for Plantaže's operations and any future privatization or restructuring, and signal to the EU that Montenegro has not adequately addressed socialist-era restitution — a long-standing benchmark in the accession process. The lack of dialogue is a missed opportunity to unlock significant economic value in one of Montenegro's most strategically located peri-urban areas.

assessments.reasoning:
This issue sits at the intersection of several critical economic policy domains for Montenegro.

**Property Rights and Investment Climate:** Secure, well-defined property rights are the bedrock of a functioning market economy. Montenegro's unresolved restitution cases — estimated to number in the tens of thousands — remain a systemic drag on economic development. The Gornja Gorica case is particularly prominent because it involves Plantaže a.d. Podgorica, one of the country's most recognizable agro-industrial enterprises and the largest vineyard in Europe managed as a single entity. When the state cannot clearly demonstrate who owns what, both domestic and foreign investors face unacceptable levels of legal risk. The World Bank Doing Business indicators and the European Commission's annual progress reports have repeatedly flagged Montenegro's incomplete restitution process and weak cadastral system as barriers to investment.

**Impact on Plantaže and Industrial Policy:** Plantaže occupies approximately 2,310 hectares of vineyards, much of it in the Ćemovsko polje area that includes Gornja Gorica land. The company has been a cornerstone of Montenegro's agro-industrial identity and export brand (Vranac wine). However, Plantaže has faced chronic financial difficulties, ownership disputes, and governance issues. If the land underlying its operations is subject to unresolved restitution claims, this creates enormous uncertainty for any restructuring, recapitalization, or privatization effort. No serious investor — whether in agriculture, food processing, or real estate development — will commit capital to assets encumbered by ownership disputes. The government's failure to engage therefore directly harms the Ministry of Economy's interest in industrial competitiveness and sectoral restructuring.

**Urban Economic Development:** Gornja Gorica is located in the immediate periphery of Podgorica, the capital and economic center of Montenegro. Land in this zone has rapidly appreciating value driven by urban expansion, infrastructure development (including proximity to major road corridors), and housing demand. Leaving large tracts of peri-urban land in legal limbo prevents their highest-value economic use — whether that is modern agriculture, residential development, commercial zones, or mixed-use projects. This represents a significant deadweight loss to the local and national economy.

**EU Accession and Rule of Law:** Chapters 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security) of the EU acquis require robust property rights enforcement. Additionally, Chapter 5 (Public Procurement) and Chapter 8 (Competition Policy) intersect with state-owned enterprise governance. The European Commission has noted in successive Montenegro progress reports that restitution remains incomplete and that state-owned enterprises like Plantaže require transparent governance. The government's silence is not merely a domestic political problem — it is an accession credibility issue.

**Labor Market Implications:** If the dispute escalates or leads to operational disruptions at Plantaže, this could affect several hundred direct employees and a broader supply chain of seasonal agricultural workers, transport, and hospitality linked to wine tourism. Conversely, a well-managed resolution that unlocks land for diverse economic uses could create new employment opportunities in construction, services, and SME development in the Podgorica metropolitan area.

**Social Stability and Business Environment:** Recurring street protests in front of Parliament over unresolved economic grievances send a negative signal to the business community. While citizens have every right to protest, the need for such action reflects institutional failure. A responsive, dialogue-oriented government would address these claims through established legal and administrative channels, reducing social friction and demonstrating governance capacity.

assessments.reasoning:
The Gornja Gorica protest touches on one of Montenegro's most fiscally sensitive unresolved issues: the restitution of property nationalized under the Yugoslav regime, particularly land currently held by or associated with the state-owned company 13. Jul Plantaže a.d. Podgorica. Several dimensions of this issue demand careful fiscal analysis.

First, regarding direct budgetary exposure: Montenegro's Law on Restitution of Property Rights and Compensation (Zakon o povraćaju oduzetih imovinskih prava i obeštećenju, adopted in 2004 and amended subsequently) establishes a framework for returning or compensating seized property. However, implementation has been notoriously slow and underfunded. The Restitution Fund (Fond za obeštećenje) has limited resources, and the state has historically delayed payments. If the Gornja Gorica claims are validated — and the 1962 nationalization for Agrokombinat is well-documented — the state faces either returning valuable agricultural land near Podgorica (now prime development territory given urban sprawl) or paying market-rate compensation. Given land values in the Podgorica basin, even conservative estimates suggest potential liabilities in the tens of millions of euros for the affected families. This represents a material contingent liability that is not adequately provisioned in the current budget.

Second, the Plantaže dimension is critical. Plantaže controls approximately 2,310 hectares of vineyards, much of it on the Ćemovsko polje plateau in and around Gornja Gorica. The company is a strategic state asset, contributing to agricultural exports (particularly Vranac wine), employment, and tourism branding. Any restitution of underlying land could fundamentally destabilize Plantaže's asset base, reduce its balance sheet value, and complicate its operational continuity. If the state is considering privatization or restructuring of Plantaže — as has been discussed periodically — unresolved land claims create a title defect that dramatically reduces the enterprise's market value and deters serious investors. This directly impacts potential privatization revenue for the state budget.

Third, from a foreign investment and EU accession perspective, the government's refusal to engage in dialogue is damaging. Chapter 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) of Montenegro's EU accession negotiations explicitly addresses property rights and rule of law. The European Commission's annual progress reports have repeatedly flagged slow restitution processes as a concern. Unresolved property disputes, particularly when accompanied by public protests and government silence, signal weak institutional capacity and legal uncertainty — factors that directly influence Montenegro's risk premium and its ability to attract foreign direct investment. The World Bank's Doing Business indicators and various property rights indices factor in the security of land tenure; Montenegro's scores are already mediocre by EU standards.

Fourth, the fiscal policy implications of inaction are worse than the implications of structured engagement. Every year of delay increases the state's eventual liability (as land values in the Podgorica metropolitan area continue to rise), accumulates interest on unresolved compensation claims, and erodes public trust. The government's current posture of silence is not a neutral fiscal position — it is an actively deteriorating one.

Finally, the social and political instability dimension has indirect fiscal costs. Sustained protests, if they escalate, can disrupt normal legislative and governmental processes, attract negative international media attention, and divert institutional resources. The symbolism of citizens protesting before Parliament over land rights — a fundamental property issue — is particularly potent in the context of Montenegro's EU aspirations and its narrative of democratic governance.
key_concerns: Unquantified contingent liability: The state has not provisioned adequate funds in the Restitution Fund for potential Gornja Gorica claims, which could amount to tens of millions of euros given current land values in the Podgorica basin.

Plantaže asset risk: Restitution of underlying land threatens the balance sheet integrity of Plantaže, one of Montenegro's most recognizable state-owned enterprises, and could derail future privatization or restructuring efforts.

Absence of dialogue escalates fiscal risk: The government's non-engagement allows legal claims to compound, increases the likelihood of costly court proceedings (including potential ECHR cases under Protocol 1, Article 1 — protection of property), and raises eventual settlement costs.

EU accession signaling: Unresolved mass property restitution and government non-responsiveness to citizen demands undermine Montenegro's Chapter 23 benchmarks and broader credibility in accession negotiations.

Foreign investor deterrence: Unclear land title and unresolved nationalization claims create systemic legal uncertainty that depresses FDI inflows, particularly in agriculture, real estate, and tourism sectors in the Podgorica region.
Rising opportunity cost: Land in and around Gornja Gorica has significant development potential; unresolved ownership disputes freeze productive use and tax revenue generation from these parcels.

## PARLIAMENTARY DEBATE TRANSCRIPT
### Skupština Crne Gore — Plenary Session
### Subject: Gornja Gorica Residents' Protest Over Nationalized Land and Government Non-Response
### Date: 16 February 2026

---

### I. OPENING — FRAMING THE ISSUE

The matter before Parliament concerns the repeated protests by residents of Gornja Gorica demanding the return of land nationalized in 1962 and transferred to the state-owned wine company Plantaže. On 14 February, residents conducted a protest march; on 16 February, they rallied directly before Parliament. The government has not publicly responded. Nine ministries have submitted formal assessments. The weighted average assessment score is 4.0 out of 10, reflecting a broadly negative evaluation of the current situation.

---

### II. MINISTRY POSITIONS — PRESENTATION OF ASSESSMENTS

#### A. The Justice and Rights Bloc (Strongly Critical)

**The Ministry of Justice** delivers the most severe assessment (3/10), characterizing the government's silence as a rule-of-law deficit that implicates constitutional guarantees under Article 58 (right to property), the European Convention on Human Rights (Protocol 1, Article 1), and EU Chapter 23 benchmarks. The Ministry argues that Montenegro's complete lack of a comprehensive denationalization or restitution law leaves victims of communist-era confiscation without any effective legal remedy — a situation that distinguishes Montenegro unfavorably from every EU member state and most advanced candidate countries. The Ministry flags anti-corruption concerns: the entanglement of Plantaže's politically sensitive ownership history with nationalized land raises questions about whether commercial or political interests are driving government inaction. The Ministry recommends immediate public acknowledgment, a 30-day timeline for structured dialogue, a Venice Commission-consulted denationalization law, an independent audit of Plantaže's landholdings, and activation of free legal aid for affected residents.

**The Ministry of EU Integration** (4/10) reinforces this position from the accession perspective, warning that the government's silence risks explicit negative citation in the European Commission's next annual progress report. The Ministry notes that Montenegro's failure to adopt a comprehensive restitution framework is a recurring criticism in progress reports and that the Plantaže land situation may constitute a state aid distortion relevant to Chapter 8 screening. The Ministry warns of potential adverse ECHR judgments that would further damage accession credibility. It recommends establishing a dedicated Property Restitution Agency funded through IPA III, proactive briefing of the EU Delegation in Podgorica, and inclusion of restitution progress as a standing item in accession coordination structures.

#### B. The Economic and Fiscal Bloc (Deeply Concerned)

**The Ministry of Economy** (3/10) frames the issue as a structural impediment to economic development. Unresolved ownership of Plantaže's underlying land effectively blocks any credible privatization, restructuring, or recapitalization of this strategically important enterprise. The Ministry emphasizes that economically valuable peri-urban land near Podgorica is frozen — generating no tax revenue, no investment, and no productive use. The repeated public protests signal to foreign investors that Montenegro lacks institutional capacity to resolve property disputes. The Ministry recommends an independent economic valuation, a comprehensive land-use strategy for the Podgorica peri-urban zone, and a resolution that preserves Plantaže's core viticultural operations while allowing legitimate restitution through partial land return of non-vineyard parcels combined with fair market compensation.

**The Ministry of Finance** (4/10) quantifies the fiscal exposure: unprovisioned contingent liabilities potentially amounting to tens of millions of euros given current Podgorica basin land values, compounded by the risk of costly court proceedings including ECHR cases. The Ministry argues the government's non-engagement is fiscally imprudent — every day of inaction compounds liabilities rather than managing them. It recommends a 60-day fiscal exposure assessment, independent land valuation, ring-fencing of Plantaže's operational land through alternative compensation mechanisms, and accelerated capitalization of the Restitution Fund through earmarked revenues.

#### C. The Security Bloc (Operational Alarm)

**The Ministry of Interior** (4/10) raises the alarm from a public order perspective: two protests in three days with zero government response creates an escalation trajectory. The Ministry warns that police are being placed in an inappropriate mediating role between citizens and an unresponsive government, straining Uprava policije resources. It flags the risk that organized crime-linked or politically motivated actors could exploit legitimate grievances, and warns that if government silence is perceived as successful in suppressing demands, other communities with similar restitution claims may adopt more aggressive tactics from the outset. The Ministry recommends designating a competent body for dialogue within 7 days — the most urgent timeline proposed by any ministry — along with de-escalation-focused policing guidelines and situational intelligence monitoring.

#### D. The Environmental and Spatial Planning Bloc (Strategic Warning)

**The Ministry of Environment** (5/10) introduces a critical dimension largely absent from other assessments: the Ćemovsko polje, where Plantaže's vineyards are located, constitutes one of the largest contiguous agricultural zones in the Podgorica basin, providing essential ecosystem services including groundwater recharge, urban cooling, carbon sequestration, and flood attenuation. The Ministry warns that Montenegro has a historical pattern of restituted agricultural land being rapidly reclassified for construction via municipal Detailed Urban Plans (DUPs) without adequate environmental assessment. Fragmentation of this green belt would worsen stormwater flooding, degrade Podgorica's climate resilience during increasing Mediterranean heat extremes, and violate obligations under EU Chapter 27. The Ministry recommends formal designation of Ćemovsko polje as a Protected Agricultural Zone, mandatory Strategic Environmental Assessment before any land transfers, and a cross-ministerial working group to develop an environmentally conditioned restitution framework.

#### E. The Social Services Bloc (Indirect but Supportive of Dialogue)

**The Ministry of Health** (5/10) acknowledges the issue falls outside its direct mandate but raises the psychosocial dimension: generational grievance since 1962 represents long-term community trauma never addressed through support mechanisms. Prolonged unresolved disputes contribute to chronic stress with cardiovascular and mental health consequences. The Ministry recommends sensitizing local health centers to increased stress-related consultations and incorporating civic unrest into public health monitoring frameworks.

**The Ministry of Education** (4/10) similarly identifies indirect but real concerns: unresolved land disputes may obstruct future school infrastructure in Podgorica's expanding suburban belt, and potential disruption to Plantaže could affect VET partnerships for agricultural training. The Ministry recommends incorporating this case into the civic education curriculum as a teaching example of democratic participation.

**The Ministry of Tourism** (4/10) warns that uncertainty over Plantaže's land tenure could undermine the planned Wine Route of Montenegro initiative and that negative media coverage during the February-April booking window could marginally impact destination perception. More broadly, unresolved nationalization claims create legal risk for tourism projects built on formerly nationalized land, particularly along the coast.

---

### III. POINTS OF CONSENSUS

1. **The government's silence is universally condemned.** Every ministry — from Justice to Health — agrees that the complete absence of public response to peaceful citizen protests is institutionally indefensible and strategically counterproductive.

2. **Structured dialogue must begin immediately.** All ministries recommend establishing a formal engagement mechanism, though proposed timelines range from 7 days (Interior) to 60 days (Finance).

3. **A comprehensive restitution law is overdue.** Multiple ministries (Justice, EU Integration, Economy, Finance) agree that Montenegro's lack of systematic denationalization legislation is a structural failure that generates cascading risks across every policy domain.

4. **EU accession is directly affected.** Six of nine ministries explicitly reference Chapter 23 benchmarks, European Commission progress reports, or ECHR jurisprudence as reasons for urgent action.

5. **Plantaže's strategic value must be preserved.** No ministry advocates for the destruction or dismantling of Plantaže; all seek a resolution that balances restitution with enterprise continuity.

6. **An independent valuation of the disputed land is necessary.** The Ministries of Finance, Economy, and Environment all call for objective assessment as a prerequisite for any resolution.

---

### IV. POINTS OF CONTENTION

1. **Conservation versus development.** The Ministry of Environment's insistence on Protected Agricultural Zone designation and mandatory SEA requirements could conflict with the Ministry of Economy's emphasis on unlocking the land's development potential and the Ministry of Finance's interest in maximizing fiscal value from resolution.

2. **Land return versus compensation.** A fundamental tension exists between the Ministry of Justice's rights-based approach (which implies actual land return where feasible) and the Ministry of Finance's fiscally cautious preference for alternative compensation mechanisms that preserve Plantaže's operational footprint.

3. **Security-led versus reform-led response.** The Ministry of Interior's focus on intelligence monitoring, contingency policing, and escalation risk implicitly treats the protest as a security management challenge, while the Ministry of Justice and Ministry of EU Integration insist it must be addressed as a rule-of-law and institutional reform priority. The balance between these approaches will define the government's posture.

4. **Priority allocation.** Ministries with neutral assessments (Health, Education, Tourism, Environment) implicitly question whether this issue merits the level of political capital and budget reallocation that the Justice-Economy-Finance bloc demands, given competing national priorities.

---

### V. OPPOSITION AND CIVIL SOCIETY PERSPECTIVES

The opposition may be expected to argue that the government's silence reflects not incompetence but deliberate protection of politically connected interests surrounding Plantaže's ownership structure. The transformation of Plantaže from a socialist-era Agrokombinat into a state-controlled enterprise whose land tenure remains unresolved after more than sixty years raises legitimate questions about who benefits from continued ambiguity. Civil society organizations focused on transitional justice and property rights are likely to frame this as part of Montenegro's broader unfinished reckoning with the communist era — noting that Montenegro lags behind Croatia, Serbia, Slovenia, and North Macedonia in adopting restitution legislation. The Ombudsman's office may face calls to investigate systemic failures in addressing historical property claims. International observers, including the EU Delegation and the Council of Europe, will be monitoring whether the government's eventual response meets the standards expected of a candidate country in advanced accession negotiations.

---

### VI. OVERALL ASSESSMENT AND VERDICT

**Verdict: NEGATIVE**

The parliamentary synthesis finds that the current situation — defined not merely by the underlying land dispute but critically by the government's complete failure to respond — is negative for Montenegro across multiple dimensions:

- **Rule of law**: The absence of a restitution framework and the government's silence represent a failure of constitutional governance.
- **EU accession**: Multiple Chapter 23 and Chapter 8 benchmarks are implicated, with real risk of negative citation in the next European Commission progress report.
- **Fiscal exposure**: Unquantified, unprovisioned contingent liabilities in the tens of millions of euros are compounding daily.
- **Public order**: The escalation trajectory is concerning and places inappropriate burden on law enforcement.
- **Economic development**: Strategically valuable land and a nationally significant enterprise are frozen in legal limbo.
- **Environmental risk**: Any eventual resolution, if handled without safeguards, could trigger irreversible loss of Podgorica's primary green infrastructure.

The Parliament notes that this situation is entirely of the government's own making. The residents' demands are not radical — they seek dialogue, not confrontation. The government possesses every tool necessary to respond: existing restitution legislation (however inadequate), inter-ministerial coordination mechanisms, and the political authority to initiate reform. Its failure to deploy any of these tools transforms a manageable policy challenge into a multi-dimensional institutional crisis.

**Parliament recommends that the government:**
1. Issue a public acknowledgment of the Gornja Gorica residents' claims within 48 hours;
2. Designate a competent inter-ministerial body to open formal dialogue within 7 days;
3. Commission independent legal and economic valuations of the disputed parcels within 60 days;
4. Initiate drafting of a comprehensive denationalization and restitution law, in consultation with the Venice Commission and drawing on regional best practices, with a target for parliamentary submission within 12 months;
5. Ensure that any resolution incorporates environmental safeguards to protect the Ćemovsko polje agricultural zone;
6. Proactively brief the EU Delegation and European Commission on the government's response plan.

---

*End of parliamentary debate synthesis. The Skupština calls upon the Government of Montenegro to treat this matter with the urgency that nine concurrent ministry assessments — none of them positive — clearly demand.*

critic_report.overall_analysis:
This is not a 'decision' by the government — it is the conspicuous absence of one, and that absence is itself a damning policy choice. Residents of Gornja Gorica are demanding something that virtually every post-communist European country has addressed through legislation: the return of or compensation for property seized under socialist-era nationalization. Montenegro's failure to create a functioning restitution framework — more than three decades after the fall of communism and more than two decades into its EU accession journey — is not an oversight. It is a deliberate choice that serves entrenched interests.

The government's total silence in response to peaceful citizen protests is the most alarming element. This is not a complex policy question that requires months of study. At minimum, a functioning democratic government acknowledges its citizens' grievances, identifies the competent institution, and commits to a timeline for dialogue. The refusal to do even this much suggests either institutional paralysis or a calculated bet that the protesters will tire and go home. Either explanation is unacceptable.

The ministry assessments are, on the whole, surprisingly thorough and substantive. The Ministries of Justice, Economy, Finance, and EU Integration produced genuinely analytical work that correctly identifies the systemic nature of the problem and its implications for EU accession, investor confidence, and rule of law. The Ministry of Environment's analysis of land fragmentation risk and the Ćemovsko polje's ecosystem services was particularly impressive and identified a concern that policymakers rarely consider. The Health and Education assessments were weaker but honest about their peripheral relevance.

However, there is a collective blind spot across all ministries: none of them dared to name the political economy of inaction. Plantaže is not just any state-owned enterprise — it has been at the center of privatization controversies, politically connected management appointments, and allegations of asset stripping for years. The government's silence almost certainly reflects the political cost of opening Plantaže's land tenure to scrutiny, because doing so would expose decades of patronage and mismanagement. The ministries dance around this with phrases like 'politically sensitive ownership history' and 'anti-corruption risk,' but none states plainly that powerful people benefit from keeping this land in Plantaže's hands.

From an EU perspective, this situation is a gift to critics of Montenegro's accession readiness. The European Commission does not need to look far for evidence of weak property rights, unresponsive governance, and unreformed state-owned enterprises — the residents of Gornja Gorica are literally standing in front of Parliament holding up the evidence. Every year of inaction strengthens the case that Montenegro is not serious about Chapter 23 reform.

The fiscal dimension is also underappreciated by the government (though the Ministry of Finance captured it well): delay is not free. Land values in the Podgorica basin are rising, which means the state's eventual restitution or compensation liability grows annually. The government is effectively running up a tab it will eventually have to pay, with interest.

Scoring the 'decision' (i.e., the government's non-response) at 2 out of 10 reflects that silence in the face of legitimate, peaceful, well-documented property claims is a governance failure by any democratic standard. It is not a 1 only because the right to protest has not been suppressed — the police have allowed the demonstrations to proceed, which is the bare constitutional minimum.

The assessment quality score of 7 reflects genuinely good analytical work by most ministries, with appropriate cross-referencing to EU acquis chapters, constitutional provisions, and sectoral implications. The main deductions are for the collective failure to address the political economy of Plantaže, the absence of any attempt to quantify the scale of claims, and the fact that Health and Education stretched rather thin to find relevance when a simple 'not within our mandate, no comment' might have been more honest.
critic_report.headline: Government's Deafening Silence on Gornja Gorica Land Theft Exposes Montenegro's Unfinished Reckoning with Communist-Era Seizures
critic_report.headline_mne: Zaglušujuća tišina Vlade o otimanju zemlje u Gornjoj Gorici otkriva neokončan obračun Crne Gore sa konfiskacijama iz komunističke ere
critic_report.overall_analysis_mne:
Ovo nije 'odluka' Vlade — to je upadno odsustvo odluke, a samo to odsustvo je razorno opredeljenje u politici. Stanovnici Gornje Gorice traže nešto što je praktično svaka postkomunistička evropska zemlja riješila zakonodavstvom: povraćaj ili kompenzaciju za imovinu oduzetu tokom nacionalizacije iz socijalističke ere. Neuspjeh Crne Gore da stvori funkcionalan okvir za restituciju — više od tri decenije nakon pada komunizma i više od dvije decenije u procesu pristupanja EU — nije previd. To je svjesna odluka koja služi ukorijenjenim interesima.

Potpuna tišina Vlade kao odgovor na mirne građanske proteste je najalarmantniji element. Ovo nije složeno pitanje politike koje zahtijeva mjesece proučavanja. Minimalno, funkcionalna demokratska vlada priznaje prigovore svojih građana, identifikuje nadležnu instituciju i obavezuje se na vremenski okvir za dijalog. Odbijanje da učini čak i toliko sugeriše ili institucionalnu paralizu ili kalkulisanu pretpostavku da će se protestanti umoriti i otići kući. Oba objašnjenja su neprihvatljiva.

Ministarske procjene su, u cjelini, iznenađujuće temeljne i suštinske. Ministarstva pravde, ekonomije, finansija i evropskih integracija su proizvela istinski analitičke radove koji pravilno identifikuju sistemsku prirodu problema i njegove implikacije za pristupanje EU, povjerenje investitora i vladavinu prava. Analiza Ministarstva ekologije o riziku fragmentacije zemljišta i ekosistemskim uslugama Ćemovskog polja bila je posebno impresivna i identifikovala je zabrinutost koju kreatори politike rijetko razmatraju. Procjene Ministarstva zdravlja i obrazovanja bile su slabije ali poštene u pogledu njihove periferne relevantnosti.

Međutim, postoji kolektivna slijepa tačka u svim ministarstvima: nijedno od njih nije smjelo imenovati političku ekonomiju nečinjenja. Plantaže nisu bilo koje državno preduzeće — godinama su u centru kontroverzi o privatizaciji, politički povezanih imenovanja menadžmenta i optužbi za rasprodaju imovine. Tišina Vlade gotovo sigurno odražava političku cijenu otvaranja pitanja zemljišnog posed Plantaža, jer bi to razotkrilo decenije patronaže i lošeg upravljanja. Ministarstva plešu oko ovoga frazama poput 'politički osjetljive historije vlasništva' i 'antikorupcijskog rizika', ali nijedno ne kaže jasno da moćni ljudi imaju koristi od zadržavanja ovog zemljišta u rukama Plantaža.

Iz perspektive EU, ova situacija je poklon kritičarima spremnosti Crne Gore za pristupanje. Evropska komisija ne mora daleko tražiti dokaze slabih imovinskih prava, nevlastite uprave i nereformisanih državnih preduzeća — stanovnici Gornje Gorice doslovno stoje ispred Skupštine držeći dokaze. Svaka godina nečinjenja jača argument da Crna Gora nije ozbiljna u pogledu reforme Poglavlja 23.

Fiskalna dimenzija je takođe potcijenjena od strane Vlade (iako ju je Ministarstvo finansija dobro obuhvatilo): odlaganje nije besplatno. Vrijednost zemljišta u podgoričkom basenu raste, što znači da državna eventualna obaveza restitucije ili kompenzacije raste godišnje. Vlada efektivno stvara račun koji će na kraju morati platiti, sa kamatom.

Ocjena 'odluke' (tj. odsustva odgovora Vlade) sa 2 od 10 odražava da je tišina pred legitimnim, mirnim, dobro dokumentovanim imovinskim zahtjevima neuspjeh upravljanja po bilo kom demokratskom standardu. Nije 1 samo zato što pravo na protest nije potisnuto — policija je dozvolila da demonstracije proteknu, što je minimalni ustavni standard.

Ocjena kvaliteta procjene od 7 odražava istinski dobar analitički rad većine ministarstava, sa odgovarajućim unakrsnim referencama na poglavlja acquis-a EU, ustavne odredbe i sektorske implikacije. Glavni odbici su zbog kolektivnog neuspjeha da se adresira politička ekonomija Plantaža, odsustva bilo kakvog pokušaja da se kvantifikuje obim zahtjeva, i činjenice da su se Zdravlje i Obrazovanje previše rastegnuli da pronađu relevantnost kada bi jednostavan 'nije u našem mandatu, bez komentara' mogao biti pošteniji.
blind_spots_mne: Nijedno ministarstvo nije adresiralo specifičan pravni status i merite zahtjeva stanovnika — koliko je jak dokumentarni dokaz vlasništva prije 1962. godine, i šta zapravo pokazuje katastar?

Nema analize trenutnog finansijskog zdravlja Plantaža i da li je kompanija uopšte održiva bez spornog zemljišta — ako Plantaže već imaju finansijske poteškoće, restitucija može ubrzati neizbježno restrukturiranje umjesto da izazove novu krizu

Nedostaje analiza koliko je porodica i hektara zapravo uključeno — obim zahtjeva određuje sve u pogledu fiskalne izloženosti, ekološkog rizika i održivosti Plantaža, a nijedno ministarstvo nije pokušalo to kvantifikovati

Nijedno ministarstvo nije ispitalo da li Plantaže plaćaju pravedne zakupnine ili naknade za korišćenje ovog zemljišta državi, ili da li kompanija efektivno prima skrivenu subvenciju kroz besplatno korišćenje nacionalizovane imovine
Potpuno odsustvo komparativne analize kako su slični zahtjevi riješeni u drugim crnogorskim opštinama — postoje li presedani koji bi mogli voditi okvir za rješenje?

Nijedno ministarstvo nije adresiralo pitanje političke ekonomije: ko ima koristi od statusa quo? Politički povezana vlasnička i upravljačka struktura Plantaža je slon u sobi koji objašnjava tišinu Vlade
Romi i druge ranjive zajednice koje su možda imale zemlju nacionalizovanu u istoj eri nisu spomenute — ovaj protest bi mogao biti vrh ledenog brijega koji utiče na više zajednica
Nijedno ministarstvo nije ispitalo da li su stanovnici već iscrpili administrativna i sudska pravna sredstva, što bi kontekstualizovalo zašto protestuju na ulicama
Nedostaje analiza uloge Ombudsmana (Zaštitnika ljudskih prava i sloboda) — da li je ova institucija angažovana, i ako nije, zašto ne?
Nema procjene medijskog landskepa i dinamike javnog mnjenja — činjenica da su četiri odvojena medija pokrila ovo sugeriše značajnu javnu simpatiju koju Vlada ignoriše uz svoj politički rizik

counter_proposal.title: Comprehensive Gornja Gorica Restitution Resolution and National Denationalization Framework
counter_proposal.executive_summary: Rather than maintaining silence while fiscal liabilities compound, social tensions escalate, and EU accession credibility erodes, the AI Government would immediately open structured dialogue with Gornja Gorica residents, launch a fast-track restitution adjudication process for Plantaže-related land claims, and use this case as a pilot for drafting Montenegro's long-overdue comprehensive Denationalization and Restitution Act. The approach balances legitimate property rights with preservation of Plantaže as a strategic agricultural and wine tourism asset, offering claimants a menu of remedies — partial land return, financial compensation via structured bonds, or equity participation in agritourism cooperatives — all conditioned on environmental safeguards that protect the Ćemovsko polje as Podgorica's critical green belt.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal:
The government's complete silence in response to two peaceful protests in three days is not a neutral position — it is an actively harmful one. It compounds fiscal liabilities, strains police resources, damages EU accession credibility, and signals institutional contempt for citizens exercising their constitutional rights. Every ministry that assessed this situation — from Justice to Finance to Interior — independently concluded that immediate engagement is necessary. This unified proposal operationalizes that consensus.

**Track 1: Immediate Response (0-30 days)**

The government must issue a public acknowledgment of the Gornja Gorica residents' demands within 48 hours. This need not concede any specific claim, but must demonstrate that the state is listening. The statement should identify the competent institutional channel for processing their claims and commit to a first formal dialogue session within 30 days. The Ministry of Interior would shift from reactive protest policing to a community liaison model, assigning a dedicated officer from the Podgorica Security Centre to maintain communication with protest organizers and de-escalate tensions.

**Track 2: Gornja Gorica Fast-Track Resolution (0-12 months)**

An inter-ministerial Restitution Task Force — comprising the Ministry of Finance (lead, as restitution authority), Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Economy, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Environment, and Ministry of Spatial Planning — would be established within 30 days with a 12-month mandate to produce a binding resolution for the Gornja Gorica claims specifically. This task force would commission three foundational assessments in parallel: (a) an independent land survey and market valuation of all disputed parcels, conducted by a certified independent appraiser; (b) a Strategic Environmental Assessment of land-use change scenarios for the Ćemovsko polje, as required by EU SEA Directive standards; and (c) an economic impact assessment of restitution scenarios on Plantaže's operations, employment, and wine tourism capacity.

Based on these assessments, the task force would offer claimants a structured menu of remedies: (1) physical land return for non-vineyard parcels where operationally feasible and environmentally appropriate; (2) fair market-value financial compensation via 10-year government bonds at 3% annual interest for parcels essential to Plantaže's core viticultural operations; (3) equity participation in a new Gornja Gorica agritourism cooperative, giving descendants of original owners a stake in wine tourism revenue through guided vineyard tours, farm stays, and local product sales; or (4) equivalent-value land swaps in designated development zones within the Podgorica spatial plan. An independent mediator, appointed by the Ministry of Justice, would facilitate negotiations between residents, Plantaže, and the Property Directorate.

**Track 3: Plantaže Asset Preservation and Restructuring**

Any resolution must preserve Plantaže's core viticultural operations — the 2,310-hectare vineyard is a strategic national asset for agricultural exports, employment, and wine tourism branding. The task force would develop a Plantaže Land Rationalization Plan that distinguishes between parcels essential for vineyard operations and non-essential holdings that can be returned or repurposed. The Ćemovsko polje wine region would be designated as a Protected Agricultural-Tourism Zone, ensuring that regardless of ownership changes, the land retains its agricultural and wine tourism function. This protects both the Wine Route of Montenegro initiative and the Šipčanik wine cellar tourism operations. Resolving land title defects would simultaneously prepare Plantaže for any future privatization or strategic partnership, potentially increasing the enterprise's market value significantly.

**Track 4: Environmental and Spatial Planning Safeguards**

The Ćemovsko polje is not merely agricultural land — it is Podgorica's largest contiguous green zone, providing groundwater recharge, urban heat island mitigation, carbon sequestration, and flood attenuation. Any fragmentation of these parcels into small private plots carries a demonstrated risk of reclassification for construction, as Montenegro's post-2000 experience with restituted land has shown. Therefore, the proposal mandates: formal designation of the Ćemovsko polje as a Protected Agricultural Zone under the Law on Agricultural Land; mandatory Environmental Impact Assessment for any future Detailed Urban Plans affecting restituted parcels; and integration of green belt protections into the updated Podgorica General Urban Plan. These are not obstacles to restitution — they are conditions that ensure restitution does not destroy an irreplaceable environmental asset.

**Track 5: National Denationalization Law (12-24 months)**

The Gornja Gorica case must not be resolved in isolation. Montenegro remains an outlier among Western Balkan and post-socialist states in lacking a comprehensive denationalization law. Using the Gornja Gorica resolution as a pilot, the Ministry of Justice would lead the drafting of a comprehensive Denationalization and Restitution Act by Q4 2027, modeled on the Croatian (1996) and Serbian (2011) frameworks and developed in consultation with the Venice Commission. This legislation would establish a permanent, independent Restitution Commission with adequate staffing, digital case management, clear procedural deadlines, and judicial review before the Administrative Court. All claimants would be guaranteed free legal aid under the existing Law on Free Legal Aid.

**Track 6: Fiscal Framework**

The Restitution Fund would be recapitalized with €15-25 million earmarked over three fiscal years (2026-2028), sourced from state property disposal revenues. The bond-based compensation mechanism spreads costs over a decade, making them manageable within Montenegro's approximately €2 billion annual budget. A comprehensive audit of all outstanding restitution claims related to former Agrokombinat land would be conducted to establish the full scope of fiscal exposure. IPA III pre-accession funding would be leveraged for institutional capacity building, including the digital case management system for the Restitution Commission.

**Track 7: Community Support and Education Integration**

Local community health centres serving Gornja Gorica would be sensitized to potential increases in stress-related consultations among affected families, with psychosocial support made available. The Ministry of Education would coordinate with spatial planning authorities to ensure that any land resolution preserves parcels needed for future school infrastructure in this rapidly growing suburban area. VET partnerships with Plantaže for agricultural training would be formalized through memoranda of understanding, independent of ownership changes. The protests themselves would be incorporated into civic education curricula as a real domestic example of democratic participation.

risks_and_tradeoffs: Political resistance: Plantaže's entanglement with politically connected interests may generate resistance to transparent land audits and title resolution. This is the single greatest implementation risk and cannot be resolved through technical measures alone — it requires sustained political commitment at the highest level

Fiscal exposure may exceed estimates: Full land valuation could reveal liabilities beyond the €15-25M provisioned. The bond-based mechanism provides a buffer, but the government must be prepared to adjust upward. Earlier engagement is fiscally preferable to delayed engagement precisely because land values in the Podgorica basin continue to appreciate

Claimant expectations vs. environmental constraints: Some Gornja Gorica residents may expect unconditional freehold land return with full development rights. The Protected Agricultural Zone designation and environmental conditionalities will limit this option. Transparent communication about why these safeguards exist — and the availability of alternative remedies — is essential to managing expectations

Plantaže operational disruption: Even a well-managed restitution process creates uncertainty for Plantaže's management and workforce during the adjudication period. The Land Rationalization Plan must clearly ring-fence core viticultural operations early in the process to minimize this risk

Legislative timeline for Denationalization Act: The 18-24 month timeline for comprehensive legislation is ambitious given Montenegro's parliamentary dynamics. If the broader law stalls, the Gornja Gorica pilot resolution must proceed independently to maintain credibility

Precedent effects: A successful Gornja Gorica resolution will trigger similar demands from other communities with unresolved nationalization-era claims. This is not a risk to be avoided — it is an inevitability to be planned for, which is precisely why the permanent Restitution Commission and Denationalization Act are essential components rather than optional additions

EU accession signaling is double-edged: While proactive engagement generates positive Chapter 23 signals, publicly acknowledging the scale of unresolved restitution claims also reveals the depth of the problem. The net effect is positive — the Commission rewards credible reform commitment over denial — but the government must be prepared for increased scrutiny

Agritourism cooperative model is untested in Montenegro: The equity participation option for claimants is innovative but lacks domestic precedent. Pilot implementation with willing families, supported by technical assistance, would be advisable before scaling
counter_proposal.title_mne: Sveobuhvatna rezolucija restitucije Gornje Gorice i nacionalni okvir denacionalizacije
counter_proposal.executive_summary_mne: Umjesto održavanja tišine dok se fiskalne obaveze uvećavaju, društvene tenzije eskaliraju i kredibilitet pristupanja EU erodira, AI Vlada bi odmah otvorila strukturisani dijalog sa stanovnicima Gornje Gorice, pokrenula ubrzani postupak adjudikacije restitucije za zemljišne zahtjeve vezane za Plantaže, i iskoristila ovaj slučaj kao pilot za izradu dugo odlagane sveobuhvatne Zakona o denacionalizaciji i restituciji Crne Gore. Pristup balansira legitimna imovinska prava sa očuvanjem Plantaža kao strateškog poljoprivrednog i vinskog turističkog resursa, nudeći podnosiocima zahtjeva meni rješenja — djelimičan povraćaj zemlje, finansijsku kompenzaciju putem strukturisanih obveznica, ili učešće u kapitalu agroturističkih zadruga — sve uslovljeno ekološkim zaštitnim mjerama koje štite Ćemovsko polje kao kritični zeleni pojas Podgorice.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal_mne:
Potpuna tišina vlade kao odgovor na dva mirna protesta u tri dana nije neutralna pozicija — to je aktivno štetna pozicija. Ona uvećava fiskalne obaveze, opterećuje policijske resurse, narušava kredibilitet pristupanja EU, i signalizira institucionalno preziranje građana koji ostvaruju svoja ustavna prava. Svako ministarstvo koje je procijenilo ovu situaciju — od Pravde do Finansija do Unutrašnjih poslova — nezavisno je zaključilo da je hitno angažovanje neophodno. Ovaj objedinjeni prijedlog operacionalizuje taj konsenzus.

**Pravac 1: Hitni odgovor (0-30 dana)**

Vlada mora izdati javno priznanje zahtjeva stanovnika Gornje Gorice u roku od 48 sati. Ovo ne mora popustiti ni po jednom konkretnom zahtjevu, ali mora pokazati da država sluša. Izjava treba identificirati nadležni institucionalni kanal za procesiranje njihovih zahtjeva i obavezati se na prvu formalnu sesiju dijaloga u roku od 30 dana. Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova bi prešlo sa reaktivnog policijskog nadzora protesta na model zajedničke veze, dodjeljivanjem namjenskog službenika iz Centra bezbjednosti Podgorica za održavanje komunikacije sa organizatorima protesta i deeskalaciju tenzija.

**Pravac 2: Ubrzano rješenje za Gornju Goricu (0-12 mjeseci)**

Međuministarska Radna grupa za restituciju — sastavljena od Ministarstva finansija (vodeće, kao organ za restituciju), Ministarstva pravde, Ministarstva ekonomije, Ministarstva poljoprivrede, Ministarstva ekologije, i Ministarstva prostornog planiranja — bi bila uspostavljena u roku od 30 dana sa 12-mjesečnim mandatom da proizvede obavezujuću rezoluciju specifično za zahtjeve Gornje Gorice. Ova radna grupa bi naručila tri temeljna procjenjivanja paralelno: (a) nezavisno istraživanje zemljišta i tržišnu procjenu svih spornih parcela, sprovedenu od strane certificiranog nezavisnog procjenjivača; (b) Stratešku procjenu uticaja na životnu sredinu scenarija promjene namjene zemljišta za Ćemovsko polje, kako je zahtijevano standardima EU Direktive o SPU; i (c) procjenu ekonomskog uticaja scenarija restitucije na poslovanje Plantaža, zapošljavanje, i kapacitet vinskog turizma.

Na osnovu ovih procjena, radna grupa bi ponudila podnosiocima zahtjeva strukturisani meni rješenja: (1) fizički povraćaj zemlje za parcele koje nisu vinogradi gdje je operativno izvodljivo i ekološki primjereno; (2) finansijska kompenzacija po fer tržišnoj vrijednosti putem 10-godišnjih državnih obveznica sa 3% godišnje kamate za parcele suštinske za osnovne vinogradarske operacije Plantaža; (3) učešće u kapitalu nove agroturističke zadruge Gornja Gorica, dajući potomcima originalnih vlasnika udio u prihodu od vinskog turizma kroz vođene obilazke vinograda, seoske boravke, i prodaju lokalnih proizvoda; ili (4) zamjena zemlje ekvivalentne vrijednosti u označenim razvojnim zonama unutar prostornog plana Podgorice. Nezavisni medijator, imenovan od strane Ministarstva pravde, bi olakšao pregovore između stanovnika, Plantaža, i Direkcije za imovinu.

**Pravac 3: Očuvanje i restrukturiranje imovine Plantaža**

Bilo koje rješenje mora očuvati osnovne vinogradarske operacije Plantaža — vinograd od 2.310 hektara je strateška nacionalna imovina za poljoprivredni izvoz, zapošljavanje, i brendiranje vinskog turizma. Radna grupa bi razvila Plan racionalizacije zemljišta Plantaža koji razlikuje parcele suštinske za operacije vinograda od nesuštinskih posjedovanja koja mogu biti vraćena ili prenamjenjena. Vinski region Ćemovsko polje bi bio označen kao Zaštićena poljoprivredno-turistička zona, osiguravajući da, bez obzira na promjene vlasništva, zemlja zadrži svoju poljoprivrednu i vinsko-turističku funkciju. Ovo štiti i inicijativu Vinska ruta Crne Gore i turističke operacije vinskog podruma Šipčanik. Rješavanje defekata zemljišnih naslova bi istovremeno pripremilo Plantaže za bilo kakvu buduću privatizaciju ili strateško partnerstvo, potencijalno značajno uvećavajući tržišnu vrijednost preduzeća.

**Pravac 4: Ekološke i prostorno-planske zaštitne mjere**

Ćemovsko polje nije samo poljoprivredno zemljište — to je najveća povezana zelena zona Podgorice, obezbeđujući punjenje podzemnih voda, ublažavanje urbanog toplotnog ostrva, sekvestraciju ugljenika, i ublažavanje poplava. Bilo kakva fragmentacija ovih parcela na male privatne parcele nosi dokazan rizik od reklasifikacije za gradnju, kao što je pokazalo crnogorsko iskustvo nakon 2000. godine sa restituisanim zemljištem. Stoga, prijedlog nalaže: formalnu oznaku Ćemovskog polja kao Zaštićene poljoprivredne zone po Zakonu o poljoprivrednom zemljištu; obaveznu Procjenu uticaja na životnu sredinu za bilo koje buduće Detaljne urbane planove koji utiču na restituisane parcele; i integraciju zaštite zelenog pojasa u ažurirani Generalni urbanistički plan Podgorice. Ovo nisu prepreke restituciji — to su uslovi koji osiguravaju da restitucija ne uništi nezamjenljivu ekološku vrijednost.

**Pravac 5: Nacionalni zakon o denacionalizaciji (12-24 mjeseca)**

Slučaj Gornje Gorice ne smije biti rješen izolovano. Crna Gora ostaje izuzetak među državama Zapadnog Balkana i post-socijalističkim državama u nedostatku sveobuhvatnog zakona o denacionalizaciji. Koristeći rezoluciju Gornje Gorice kao pilot, Ministarstvo pravde bi vodilo izradu sveobuhvatnog Zakona o denacionalizaciji i restituciji do Q4 2027, modeliranog po hrvatskim (1996) i srpskim (2011) okvirima i razvijenog u konsultaciji sa Venecijanskom komisijom. Ovo zakonodavstvo bi uspostavilo stalnu, nezavisnu Komisiju za restituciju sa adekvatnim kadrom, digitalnim upravljanjem predmetima, jasnim proceduralnim rokovima, i sudskom revizijom pred Upravnim sudom. Svim podnosiocima zahtjeva bi bila garantovana besplatna pravna pomoć po postojećem Zakonu o besplatnoj pravnoj pomoći.

**Pravac 6: Fiskalni okvir**

Fond za restituciju bi bio rekapitalizovan sa 15-25 miliona eura izdvojenih tokom tri fiskalne godine (2026-2028), iz prihoda od raspolaganja državnom imovinom. Mehanizam kompenzacije baziran na obveznicama raspoređuje troškove tokom decenije, čineći ih upravljivim u okviru crnogorskog budžeta od približno 2 milijarde eura godišnje. Sveobuhvatna revizija svih neispunjenih zahtjeva za restituciju vezanih za zemljište bivšeg Agrokombinata bi bila sprovedena radi utvrđivanja punog obima fiskalne izloženosti. IPA III pretpristupna sredstva bi bila iskorištena za izgradnju institucionalnog kapaciteta, uključujući digitalni sistem upravljanja predmetima za Komisiju za restituciju.

**Pravac 7: Podrška zajednici i integracija obrazovanja**

Lokalni domovi zdravlja koji služe Gornjoj Gorici bi bili senzibilisani na potencijalne povećane konsultacije vezane za stres među pogođenim porodicama, sa dostupnom psihosocijalnom podrškom. Ministarstvo prosvjete bi koordiniralo sa organima prostornog planiranja kako bi se osiguralo da bilo koje rješenje zemljišta očuva parcele potrebne za buduću školsku infrastrukturu u ovom brzo rastućem pригородnom području. Partnerstva stručnog obrazovanja i obuke sa Plantažama za poljoprivrednu obuku bi bila formalizovana kroz memorandume o razumijevanju, nezavisno od promjena vlasništva. Sami protesti bi bili inkorporisani u nastavni plan i program građanskog obrazovanja kao stvarni domaći primjer demokratskog učešća.

risks_and_tradeoffs_mne: Politički otpor: Upletenost Plantaža sa politički povezanim interesima može generisati otpor transparentnim revizijama zemljišta i rješavanju naslova. Ovo je najveći pojedinačni rizik implementacije i ne može se riješiti samo tehničkim mjerama — zahtijeva trajnu političku posvećenost na najvišem nivou

Fiskalna izloženost može preći procjene: Puna procjena zemljišta može otkriti obaveze izvan rezervisanih 15-25M €. Mehanizam baziran na obveznicama pruža bafer, ali vlada mora biti spremna za povećanje prema gore. Ranije angažovanje je fiskalno poželjnije od odloženog angažovanja upravo zato što vrijednosti zemljišta u Podgoričkom basenu nastavljaju da rastu

Očekivanja podnosilaca zahtjeva nasuprot ekološkim ograničenjima: Neki stanovnici Gornje Gorice mogu očekivati bezuslovni povraćaj zemlje u potpunom vlasništvu sa punim pravima na razvoj. Označavanje Zaštićene poljoprivredne zone i ekološki uslovi će ograničiti ovu opciju. Transparentna komunikacija o tome zašto ove zaštitne mjere postoje — i dostupnost alternativnih rješenja — je suštinska za upravljanje očekivanjima

Operativni poremećaj Plantaža: Čak i dobro upravljan proces restitucije stvara neizvjesnost za menadžment i radnu snagu Plantaža tokom perioda adjudikacije. Plan racionalizacije zemljišta mora jasno odvojiti osnovne vinogradarske operacije rano u procesu kako bi se minimizirao ovaj rizik

Zakonodavni hronoločki plan za Zakon o denacionalizaciji: Hronoločki plan od 18-24 mjeseca za sveobuhvatno zakonodavstvo je ambiciozan s obzirom na crnogorsku parlamentarnu dinamiku. Ako širi zakon stagnira, pilot rezolucija Gornje Gorice mora nezavisno nastaviti kako bi se održao kredibilitet

Efekti precedenta: Uspješna rezolucija Gornje Gorice će pokrenuti slične zahtjeve drugih zajednica sa neriješenim zahtjevima iz ere nacionalizacije. Ovo nije rizik koji treba izbjeći — to je neizbježnost za koju treba planirati, što je upravo razlog zašto su stalna Komisija za restituciju i Zakon o denacionalizaciji suštinske komponente a ne opcionalni dodaci

Signaliziranje pristupanja EU je dvosjekli mač: Dok proaktivno angažovanje generiše pozitivne signale Poglavlja 23, javno priznavanje razmjera neriješenih zahtjeva za restituciju takođe otkriva dubinu problema. Neto efekat je pozitivan — Komisija nagrađuje kredibilnu predanost reformi nad negiranjem — ali vlada mora biti spremna za pojačanu kontrolu

Model agroturističke zadruge je neistestiran u Crnoj Gori: Opcija učešća u kapitalu za podnosioce zahtjeva je inovativna ali nema domaći precedent. Pilot implementacija sa voljnim porodicama, podržana tehničkom pomoći, bi bila preporučljiva prije skaliranja
